CatDescriptText: Mr. David Stokes, manager, Virginia's Tavern, 1701 Wylie Avenue and Mrs. Adelbert Brown, cook, Roselia Foundling Home, 148 Flavel Street, were part of the Pittsburghers Speak Up column published in Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, October 12, 1957, pg. 2 with question: "Do you think the Little Rock, Ark. school integration incident will gain more financial support for the NAACP in its continuing fight for equal rights?" Mr. David Stokes's answer reads: "I think it will help.  I believe every colored student has a right to go to school.  They must have an education in these times."  Mrs. Adelbet Brown's answer reads: "Yes, I do.  I can't see why our sons and brothers, who died in foxholes with white boys, can't go to school with their Southern relatives."
TitMainTitle: Group portrait of David Stokes, and Mrs. Adelbert Brown wearing dark coat with safety pin at collar, standing on sidewalk with stores, including one with glass block and sign inscribed "...ng Room [O]pen"
